name: MD5
description: Fast but broken (collisions). OK for non-security checksums only.

name: MD4
description: Older than MD5 and insecure; academic interest only.

name: SHA-1
description: 160-bit hash now deprecated due to practical collisions.

name: SHA-224
description: Truncated SHA-256; useful when a shorter digest is needed.

name: SHA-256
description: Widely used 256-bit hash from the SHA-2 family.

name: SHA-384
description: 384-bit output; based on SHA-512 with truncation.

name: SHA-512
description: 512-bit output; performs well on 64-bit CPUs.

name: SHA-512/224
description: SHA-512 with 224-bit truncation; niche use.

name: SHA-512/256
description: SHA-512 with 256-bit truncation; drop-in alt to SHA-256.

name: SHA3-224
description: Keccak-based, sponge construction; 224-bit digest.

name: SHA3-256
description: Keccak; modern alternative to SHA-2 with different design.

name: SHA3-384
description: Keccak; larger output for higher collision resistance.

name: SHA3-512
description: Keccak; 512-bit digest; conservative choice.

name: SHAKE128
description: XOF (extensible-output); you choose the output length.

name: SHAKE256
description: Stronger XOF variant; choose any output size.

name: BLAKE2s
description: Secure, very fast; supports keyed MAC, salt, personalization.

name: BLAKE2b
description: 64-bit-optimized sibling of BLAKE2s; common in file hashing.

name: BLAKE3
description: Modern, tree-hashed; extremely fast with parallelism and key derivation mode.

name: RIPEMD-160
description: 160-bit hash; seen in Bitcoin address pipelines (with SHA-256).

name: Whirlpool
description: 512-bit hash designed by Rijmen/Barreto; less common today.

name: Tiger
description: 192-bit hash optimized for 64-bit CPUs; legacy usage.

name: Snefru
description: Early hash function by Ralph Merkle; mainly historical.

name: CRC32
description: Error-detecting checksum (ZIP, PNG); not for security.

name: CRC64
description: 64-bit CRC variants (e.g., ECMA-182) for larger data streams.

name: Adler-32
description: Simple checksum (zlib); faster than CRC but weaker detection.

name: MurmurHash3
description: Fast non-crypto hash for hash tables (32/128-bit).

name: xxHash
description: Extremely fast non-crypto hashing; great for checksums.

name: CityHash / FarmHash
description: Google’s fast non-crypto hash family for strings.

name: AES-CBC
description: AES in CBC mode; needs key + IV + padding; no integrity by itself.

name: AES-CTR
description: AES in counter mode; turns AES into a stream cipher; needs nonce.

name: AES-GCM
description: AEAD mode (encrypt + authenticate); needs key, nonce, optional AAD.

name: AES-CCM
description: AEAD mode for constrained devices; tradeoffs vs GCM.

name: ChaCha20
description: High-speed stream cipher; robust and fast on all CPUs.

name: ChaCha20-Poly1305
description: AEAD mode combining ChaCha20 with Poly1305 MAC; TLS 1.3 standard.

name: 3DES
description: Triple DES; legacy and insecure; phased out.

name: Blowfish
description: 64-bit block cipher; legacy due to small block size.

name: Twofish
description: AES finalist; 128-bit block cipher; solid security but less common.

name: Serpent
description: AES finalist; very conservative security margin; slower.

name: Camellia
description: Japanese cipher with AES-like properties; standardized internationally.

name: IDEA
description: 64-bit block cipher; used in early PGP; now mostly legacy.

name: RSA-OAEP
description: RSA encryption with OAEP padding for semantic security.

name: RSA-PSS
description: RSA signature scheme with randomized padding; recommended over PKCS#1 v1.5.

name: ECDSA
description: Elliptic-curve digital signature algorithm; widely used with curves like P-256.

name: Ed25519
description: Modern elliptic curve signature on Curve25519; fast, deterministic, and secure.

name: Ed448
description: Larger EdDSA elliptic curve signature scheme; higher security margin.

name: X25519
description: Key agreement scheme using Curve25519; used in TLS 1.3 and modern protocols.

name: X448
description: Key agreement scheme using Curve448; larger keys for higher security.

name: ElGamal
description: Probabilistic public-key encryption scheme; mainly of historical and academic interest.

name: PBKDF2
description: Password-based key derivation with salt and configurable iterations; widely supported.

name: scrypt
description: Memory-hard password hashing function; resistant to GPU/ASIC cracking.

name: bcrypt
description: Password hashing function with adaptive cost factor; stores salt and cost in output.

name: Argon2id
description: Winner of the Password Hashing Competition; memory-hard and side-channel resistant.

name: HKDF
description: HMAC-based key derivation (extract-then-expand) with optional salt and info parameters.

name: HMAC
description: Keyed-hash message authentication code using secure hash functions like SHA-256.

name: CMAC
description: Cipher-based message authentication code standardized by NIST; often used with AES.

name: Base64
description: Binary-to-text encoding; widely used for data transport and embedding.

name: Base32
description: Text encoding with case-insensitivity and limited alphabet; useful for URLs.

name: Hex
description: ASCII ↔ hexadecimal string conversion; widely used for debugging and representation.

name: URL Encode
description: Percent-encode reserved characters for safe use in URIs.

name: Unicode Normalize
description: Convert and normalize between UTF-8/16/32 using NFC, NFD, NFKC, or NFKD forms.

name: Binary ↔ Text
description: Represent bytes as binary bit strings or decode binary strings back to text.

name: ROT13
description: Simple Caesar shift cipher that rotates letters by 13; used for light obfuscation.

name: Vigenere Cipher
description: Historical polyalphabetic cipher using a repeating key; cryptographically broken but educational.

name: XOR Cipher
description: Toy cipher that XORs plaintext with a key; insecure but useful for demonstrations.

name: Endian Swap
description: Convert integers between little-endian and big-endian byte orders.

name: Luhn Checksum
description: Mod-10 checksum used in credit card numbers and other identifiers.

name: UUID v4/v5
description: Universally unique identifiers: random v4 or name-based v5 using SHA-1.

name: Case Transform & Normalize
description: Convert text to upper/lower/case-fold and standardize whitespace or line endings.
